Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Human Adaptation to Long Term Environmental Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
MS Katharine Napora and Dr. Victor Thompson of the University of Georgia will undertake research on the effects of climate shifts on the Native American groups who lived along the Georgia Coast from 4500 to 3100 years ago. This research will clarify the temporal relationships between abandonments of coastal shell ring village sites and environmental change. This research into the dynamics of human-environmental interactions on the Georgia Coast contributes to broader knowledge of responses to major climatic change, long-term environmental trends, and differential resilience during pivotal transitions in the southeastern U.S. This project will contribute information about how such groups were able to adapt to dramatic ecological shifts. This work will also provide opportunities both for undergraduate researchers to gain experience in dendrochronological methodologies and for the broader public to learn about the deep cultural and environmental history of the Southeast coast through outreach and educational events held during the course of the project.

To conduct this research, the project will examine terminal radiocarbon dates from shell middens and create a 6000-year bald cypress ringwidth chronology from excavated samples from the region. Dendrochronology is a methodology uniquely suited for an integrated study of events experienced at the human timescale and understood within the context of a deep time framework. Using tree-ring data combined with modeling the final occupational dates of large terminal Late Archaic sites, this research aims to reconstruct climatic conditions and provide a more precise timeline of shell ring abandonments for the northern Georgia Coast. This study will generate annual-scale data on environmental conditions during this period and will model extant and new radiocarbon dates from shell ring and shell midden sites to compare to the dendrochronological sequence, allowing for greater precision in understanding the timing of shifts in subsistence and settlement traditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During periods of major, rapid environmental changes, how long can coastal-dependent lifeways be maintained, and are some coastal areas better buffered than others? This project examines a period of major cultural change in the Southeast U.S. about 3500 years ago during which groups who had for centuries lived year-round in large island settlements, subsisting largely on estuary resources like oysters and catfish, quite rapidly changed their lifestyles, living instead in smaller, more mobile groups on the mainland. We radiocarbon dated new archaeological sites where people lived prior to this period of change; the radiocarbon dates support the existing hypothesis that people living in deltaic regions of the Georgia Coast were able to continue their lifeways for two or three hundred more years than people living in non-deltaic regions. To determine whether environmental change was a factor in this societal shift, we examined ancient trees buried for hundreds or thousands of years deep in the coastal mud. Together, these ancient trees span from about 5700 years before present to today. Since trees lay down one ring every year and the width and characteristics of tree rings are based largely on environmental factors, tree-ring analyses allow us to reconstruct what the ancient coastal environment was like on a year-by-year basis. Our tree-ring analyses to determine annual environmental conditions is ongoing, but it appears that the majority of estuarine-dependent people on the coast were able to weather at least a century and a half of increasing environmental fluctuation before changing their way of life.  

As part of this project, we have provided tree-ring analysis training to undergraduates as well as to diverse groups through public outreach events, including the Atlanta Science Expo, middle and high schools and summer camps, football game science outreach booths, and meetings of local archaeology clubs. We plan to hold another outreach event at the location of the field site in Darien, Georgia, in Spring 2020 to present our findings to community members.
